content: Peru protests: Machu Picchu closed indefinitely and tourists stranded - BBC NewsBBC HomepageSkip to contentAccessibility HelpYour accountHomeNewsSportReelWorklifeTravelFutureMore menuMore menuSearch BBCHomeNewsSportReelWorklifeTravelFutureCultureMusicTVWeatherSoundsClose menuBBC NewsMenuHomeWar in UkraineCoronavirusClimateVideoWorldUS & CanadaUKBusinessTechMoreScienceStoriesEntertainment & ArtsHealthIn PicturesReality CheckWorld News TVNewsbeatLong ReadsWorldAfricaAsiaAustraliaEuropeLatin AmericaMiddle EastPeru protests: Machu Picchu closed indefinitely and tourists strandedPublished5 hours agoShareclose panelShare pageCopy linkAbout sharingImage source, Getty ImagesImage caption, Peruvian authorities say those with tickets to Machu Picchu can be refundedBy Kathryn ArmstrongBBC NewsPeru has closed its famous tourist site Machu Picchu indefinitely over the ongoing protests against the country's president.The government said it closed the site, and the Inca trail hike leading up to it, to protect tourists and citizens.Hundreds of people, mostly foreigners, are currently stranded at the foot of the 15th Century Inca citadel.Dozens of people have been killed in weeks of violent protests, which began when Peru's previous leader was ousted.Rail services to Machu Picchu were suspended on Thursday, after train tracks were damaged by protesters.There are 417 tourists currently stuck at the site, unable to get out because of that damage, tourism minister Luis Fernando Helguero said at a news conference on Saturday. More than 300 of them are foreigners, he added.They are not the first visitors to be stranded at Machu Picchu because of civil unrest - last month, hundreds of tourists were airlifted out after being stuck there for several days.Sitting high on a mountain in the Andes, Machu Picchu is considered one of the new seven wonders of the world. It is hugely popular with tourists, with around a million people visiting every year. Some visitors arrive at Machu Picchu via the Inca Trail, which is a famous multi-day hike. In a statement, Peru's culture ministry said that those who had already bought tickets for the site would be able to use them for one month after the end of the demonstrations, or get a refund.Demonstrators in Peru are demanding fresh elections and calling for the new President, Dina Boluarte, to stand down, which she has so far refused to do. They want her left-wing predecessor, Pedro Castillo, who is in jail and facing charges of rebellion and conspiracy, to be released. Mr Castillo denies the accusations and insists that he is still Peru's legitimate leader.Image source, Getty ImagesImage caption, Waves of visitors have been left stranded at Machu Picchu in recent weeks due to protests disrupting transportAuthorities announced on Saturday that another protester had died following demonstrations in the southern region of Puno, where police stations were set on fire. At least 58 Peruvians have been injured in the protests, according to a report from Peru's ombudsman.In the latest clashes, roads were blocked and police fired tear gas at stone-throwing demonstrators in the capital, Lima. The European Union has condemned the widespread violence and what it called the "disproportionate" use of force by the police.In a statement, it called for "urgent steps to restore calm".Dina Boluarte: Peru's first female presidentPeru has been through years of political turmoil, which came to a head when Mr Castillo was arrested last month for trying to dissolve Congress.Ms Boluarte has resisted calls to step down, including from some regional governors, and earlier this week urged Peruvians to ensure their protests were peaceful.More on this storyMore deaths reported in latest Peru protests2 days agoRelated TopicsPeruTop StoriesMachu Picchu shut indefinitely over Peru protestsPublished5 hours agoBrazil's army chief sacked after Congress riotsPublished2 hours agoCanada settles $2.8bn residential schools lawsuitPublished1 hour agoFeaturesJapan was the future but it's stuck in the pastArdern burnout shows toll of stress on world leadersMÃ¥neskin show the 'dark side of fame' on new albumWhy Indian epic film RRR is charming the WestWhat weapons are being supplied to Ukraine?Superforecasters: The people who can actually see into the futureRomanian teens explain how Andrew Tate approached themThe secrets of a perfect break-up songShould China worry about its shrinking population?Elsewhere on the BBCThe simple error that 16% of us makeGen Z's latest surprising obsessionA return to old-school Canadian glamourMost Read1Buzz Aldrin marries for the fourth time, aged 932Machu Picchu shut indefinitely over Peru protests3Canada settles $2.8bn residential schools lawsuit4Tennessee fires officials after execution errors5Biden's chief of staff to step down - summary:
-Hundreds of tourists are stranded at Machu Picchu after the site was closed indefinitely due to the violence in Peru.
-The protests have been ongoing for two weeks and have resulted in the death of at least two people.
-Dina Boluarte, Peru's first female president, has resisted calls to step down and urged Peruvians to ensure their protests were peaceful.
-More deaths have been reported in the latest protests.
